sizeScaleTheorem.title: The Size Scale Theorem: Reality from Cogito to Evolution
sizeScaleTheorem.description: A unifying framework that integrates philosophy, science, and ethics, emphasizing an infinite continuum of existence and the interplay of distinction vs. anti-distinction.

chapters.title: Cogito as the Foundation of Certain Truth

sections.content: Descartes’ cogito highlights the undeniable truth of the thinking self, emphasizing distinction between self and everything else.
Anti-distinction reminds us that reality might be one unified whole, despite the apparent separation required for analysis.
Infinity implies no ultimate boundary in size or time; reality stretches from quantum realms to cosmic expanses.
Studying phenomena at different scales reveals a continuous web linking physics, biology, and cosmology.
Mass and energy are interconvertible; spacetime weaves them into a single fabric affecting every scale of reality.
Evolution applies broadly—wherever variation, selection, and adaptation emerge, complexity can increase.
Recognizing all things as linked fosters empathy; at the same time, we respect distinctions to acknowledge individual roles and perspectives.

sizeScaleTheorem.conclusion: By combining distinction, anti-distinction, infinite scaling, and evolution, the Size Scale Theorem urges us to see ourselves as part of an evolving cosmic whole—and to act responsibly within it.
furtherReading: Alfred North Whitehead, Process and Reality
Karl Popper, Objective Knowledge: An Evolutionary Approach
Brian Greene, The Fabric of the Cosmos
